intro: Pourthiaea laevis var. villosa, commonly known as the woolly milkweed, is a flowering plant native to parts of Africa. It is characterized by its hairy, gray-green leaves and clusters of small, pale yellow flowers. The plant produces a milky sap, which is a common feature among plants in the Apocynaceae family. It thrives in arid and semi-arid environments, often growing in rocky or sandy soils. The flowers attract various pollinators, including bees and butterflies, contributing to its ecological importance.
